facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 376 to 379 of 1960 filed by assessee Company.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal Nos. 376 to 379 of 1960. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated September 18, 1958, of Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 101 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 18, 1958, of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 101 of 1954.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J. on August 31, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. August 31. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J. -These are four appeals

facts.text: Four appeals by assessee Company Karanpura Development Co., Ltd. in respect of assessment years 1949-50 and 1950-51 and two chargeable accounting periods under Business Profits Tax Act from January 1, 1948 to December 31, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: These are four appeals filed by the assessee Company  Karanpura Development Co., Ltd.  in respect of two assessment years, 1949-50 and 1950-51 and two chargeable accounting periods under the Business Profits Tax Act, January 1, 1948, to December 31, 1949.

facts.text: High Court of Calcutta dated September 18, 1958 answered question whether salami received for sub-leases are trading receipts assessable under Income-tax Act in affirmative against assessee.

anchor.surface_text: By these appeals, the assessee Company impugns the judgment of the High Court of Calcutta dated September 18, 1958, answering a companymon question whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the sums received as salami by the asseseee for granting sub-leases were trading receipts in its hands and the amount of profit therein is assessable under the Indian Income-tax Act in the affirmative and against the assessee Company.

facts.text: In 1915, Court of Wards granted prospecting licence to Messrs. Bird Co. for Karanpura Coal Fields area, for 12 years renewable for another 12 years.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case are as follows in 1915, the Court of Wards representing the proprietor of the Ramgarh Estate gra- nted a prospecting licence to Messrs. Bird Co., of an area of companyl-bearing lands described as the Karanpura Coal Fields. The, licence was for 12 years but was renewable for .another term of 12 years.

facts.text: Assessee Company Karanpura Development Co., Ltd. incorporated in 1920.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee Company was incorporated in 1920.

facts.text: On May 30, 1921, Messrs. Bird and Co. assigned rights under prospecting licence to assessee Company.

anchor.surface_text: On May 30, 1921, Messrs. Bird and CO., assigned rights under the prospecting licence to the assessee Company.

facts.text: Assessee Company acquired coal mining leases over areas aggregating 20,000 standard bighas.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee Company then acquired from time to time diverse companyl mining leases over areas aggregating 20,000 standard bighas.

facts.text: Assessee Company developed coal fields by providing communication etc. and subleased to collieries and companies.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee Company developed these companyl fields by providing means of companymunication, etc., and then subleased them to companylieries and other companypanies.

facts.text: Head leases term 999 years; sub-leases balance minus 2 days.

anchor.surface_text: In the head leases which the assessee Company had obtained, the term was 999 years. In the sub-leases the term was the balance of the period minus 2 days.

facts.text: Assessee Company did no other business: never worked coal fields, never acquired or sold coal by sub-lessees.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from obtaining head leases, developing the companyl fields and subleasing its rights, the assessee Company admittedly did number do any business. It never worked the companyl fields with a view to raising companyl number did it acquire or sell companyl raised by the sub-lessees.

facts.text: Assessee paid salami at Rs. 40 per standard bigha for head leases, agreed to pay royalties.

anchor.surface_text: As a companydition of the acquisition of the head leases, the assessee Company had paid salami at the rate of Rs. 40 per standard bigha, and had agreed to pay, royalty at certain rates.

facts.text: From sub-lessees, assessee charged salami Rs. 400 per standard bigha and higher royalties.

anchor.surface_text: From the sub-lessees, the assessee Company charged salami at the rate of Rs. 400 per standard bigha and royalties at higher rates.

facts.text: For assessment year 1949-50, assessee realised Rs. 19,14,035 as salami.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year, 1949-50, the assessee Company realised Rs. 19,14,035 as salami for the mining subleases granted in the relevant account year,

facts.text: For assessment year 1950-51, assessee realised Rs. 3,96,000 as salami.

anchor.surface_text: and in the assessment year, 1950-5 1, it realised Rs. 3,96,000 on the same account.

facts.text: Assessee admitted enhanced royalties income taxable.

anchor.surface_text: We are number companycerned with the income of assessee Company arising from the enhanced royalties, because the assessee Company admitted that that income would be taxable.

facts.text: Assessee contention: excess salami on capital account, not assessable for IT or BPT.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee Companys companytention that the excess amount realised by way of increased salami was on capital account and companyld neither be included in the assessable income for purposes of income- tax number in the profits for purposes of business profits tax ,

facts.text: Two IT and two BPT orders passed on January 30, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: as rejected. Two orders in the income-tax cases and two in the business profits tax cases were passed on January 30, 1952.

facts.text: Appeals to Appellate Assistant Commissioner dismissed on March 31, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee Company filed four appeals before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who dismissed them on March 31, 1953.

facts.text: Appeals to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal dismissed by common order December 31, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Four appeals were then filed before the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta Bench, but were dismissed by a companymon order dated December 31, 1953.

facts.text: Tribunal referred common question to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal was then moved for a reference in all the four appeals, and the companymon question to which we have referred, was raised and referred by the Tribunal with the result already indicated.

facts.text: Tribunal and High Court held acquiring head leases and granting sub-leases carrying on business, salami profits taxable.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal as well as the High Court held that in acquiring the head leases and in granting the sub-leases, the assessee Company was carrying on a business within its Memorandum of Association and the increased salami received from the sublessees represented profits of that business liable to be included in the assessable income for income- tax purposes and in the profits, for purposes of the business profits tax.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds High Court and Tribunal conclusions right, salami trading receipts.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court rightly answered the question against the assessee Company.
The case was certified to this Court by the High Court under s. 66A  2  of the Income- tax Act

arguments.claim: Tribunal and High Court held that acquiring head leases and granting sub-leases was carrying on business within MoA and increased salami represented profits taxable under IT Act and BPT Act

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal as well as the High Court held that in acquiring the head leases and in granting the sub-leases, the assessee Company was carrying on a business within its Memorandum of Association and the increased salami received from the sublessees represented profits of that business liable to be included in the assessable income for income- tax purposes and in the profits, for purposes of the business profits tax.

arguments.claim: Income-tax charged on total income including all income, profits or gains from whatever source under ss.3,4; heads under s.6 exclusive; profits of business under s.10

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Act provides, inter alia, that income-tax shall be charged on the, total income of every companypany. Under s.4 1 , total income includes all income, profits or gains from whatever source derived, Section 6 then enumerates six heads of income chargeable to income-tax.

arguments.claim: Business includes any trade, commerce or any adventure or concern in the nature of trade under s.2(4)

anchor.surface_text: In s. 2 4  of the Indian Income-tax Act, business has been defined to include any trade, companymerce or any manufacture or any adventure or companycern in the nature of trade., companymerce.or manufacture.

arguments.claim: Assessee's activities constitute profit-making scheme: not mere realization of security but gain in operation of business per Californian Copper test

anchor.surface_text: Is the sum of gain that has been made a mere enhancement of value by realising a security, or it is a gain made in an operation of business in carrying out a scheme for profit- making ?

arguments.claim: In Kamakshya Narain Singh, salami was capital for proprietor as landowner selling property, not business; different for assessee company turning to account

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, in Kamakshya Narain Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1  the Privy Council made a distinction between sums received as royal. ties and Salami by the proprietor of the Ramgarh, Estate holding the former to be income from other sources within s. 12 of the Act, and the latter as a payment on capital account but the, facts were different.

arguments.claim: Objects of company and nature of operations determine if business; company formed to acquire, develop, sub-lease mining rights for profit

anchor.surface_text: The decision in this case must, therefore, turn upon the objects for which the Company was formed, and whether one of the objects of the Company was to develop and sell leases and leaseholds with an eye to making profit and what its activity was, in relation to its objects.

arguments.claim: British South Africa Co.: sums from sub-grants of concessions in shares etc. income from business of turning rights to account

anchor.surface_text: The next case is British South Africa Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1 . In that case, the assessee was the British South Africa Co., which was incorporated, inter alia, for carrying into effect companycessions and agreements which had been made by certain chiefs of South Africa and such other companycessions which the Company might acquire.

arguments.claim: East India Prospecting Syndicate: no business as partnership holding property, collecting rents; proviso s.2(5) EPT not applicable; income under s.9 not s.10

anchor.surface_text: the proviso to s. 2 5  of the Excess Profits Tax Act, which defined business in certain circumstances, was number applicable, If this sub-lease had been granted by a limited companypany or by an incorporated society the net profit companyld be regarded as profits for the purposes of Excess Profits Tax Act by reason of the proviso to Section 2 5  of the Act.

arguments.claim: Fry v Salisbury: rents from letting rooms as landowner under Sch A, not trade under Sch D; ancillary services separate

anchor.surface_text: The last case relied upon is Fry v. Salisbury House Estate Ltd.  2  already mentioned. in this Judgment. Salisbury House was a building with 800 rooms. A companypany was formed for the express purpose of acquiring it and utilising it.

arguments.claim: Assessee's MoA objects (cl.1,52) and activities (acquire 20k bighas, develop, multiple sub-leases to collieries) show trading business, salami stock-in-trade profit under s.10 not s.9

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court rightly answered the question against the assessee Company. The assessee Company having secured a large tract of companyl-bearing land parcelled and developed it into kind of stock-in-trade to be profitably dealt with.

arguments.claim: Income does not include fixed capital realization; circulating capital turned over in profit-making is revenue

anchor.surface_text: But whatever income may include or mean it is However, clear that it does number include fixed capital or the realising of fixed Capital by turning it into some other form of capital or money. Fixed capital is something which the owner keeps in his possession but turns to profit circulating capital However, is turned over in the process of profit making.

holdings.text: The High Court rightly answered the question against the assessee Company: the sums received as salami for granting sub-leases were trading receipts assessable under the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court rightly answered the question against the assessee Company. The assessee Company having secured a large tract of coal-bearing land parcelled and developed it into kind of stock-in-trade to be profitably dealt with.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee's acquisition, development, and sub-leasing of mining leases per MoA constitutes trading business; salami is profit from stock-in-trade under s.10, not capital or property income.

holdings.text: The assessee Company was carrying on a business of trading in mining leases by acquiring head leases, developing coal fields, and granting sub-leases.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from these operations that the assessee Company having secured a large tract of coal-bearing land parcelled and developed it into kind of stock-in-trade to be profitably dealt with. The assessee Company extended its business along these lines acquiring fresh fields.

holdings.reasoning_summary: MoA clauses 1 and 52 authorize acquiring and turning to account mining rights; extensive sub-leasing to multiple collieries shows trading activity within s.2(4) definition including adventure in nature of trade.

holdings.text: The salami receipts represent revenue profits from business, not realization of fixed capital.

anchor.surface_text: But whatever income may include or mean it is clear that it does not include fixed capital or the realising of fixed Capital by turning it into some other form of capital or money. Fixed capital is something which the owner keeps in his possession but turns to profit circulating capital however, is turned over in the process of profit making.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mining leases treated as circulating capital turned over for profit via sub-leasing at enhanced salami; distinguishes fixed capital kept for yield vs. traded for gain.

holdings.text: The gain from salami is made in an operation of business in carrying out a scheme for profit-making, not mere enhancement of value by realising a security.

anchor.surface_text: Is the sum of gain that has been made a mere enhancement of value by realising a security, or it is a gain made in an operation of business in carrying out a scheme for profit-making ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Californian Copper Syndicate test to facts: company formed to acquire and profitably deal in mining rights; sub-leasing speculative trading venture.

holdings.text: Heads of income under s.6 are mutually exclusive; income from business under s.10 cannot be taxed under s.9 as property income.

anchor.surface_text: These heads are in a sense exclusive of one another and income which falls within one head cannot be assigned to, or taxed under another head.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Salami assigned to business profits s.10; distinguishes cases like East India Prospecting and Commercial Properties where mere rent collection from single property was s.9.

holdings.text: There is a distinction between a landowner/proprietor granting leases (capital/revenue from property) and a company turning mining leases to account as stock-in-trade in business.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, in Kamakshya Narain Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax the Privy Council made a distinction between sums received as royalties and Salami by the proprietor of the Ramgarh Estate holding the former to be income from other sources within s. 12 of the Act, and the latter as a payment on capital account but the facts were different.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Kamakshya involved proprietor selling property rights; assessee company exploits leases commercially per objects and operations, per Korean Syndicate emphasis on company purpose.

holdings.text: The assessee's activities go beyond mere collection of rents/royalties or management as landowner; constitute trading resulting in salami as business profits.

anchor.surface_text: The dividing line is difficult to find but in the case of a company with its professed objects and the manner of its activities and the nature of its dealings I with its property, it is possible to say on which side the operations fall, and to what head the income is to be assigned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Fry v. Salisbury (landowner letting with services) and others; assessee parcels large areas, develops, multiple sub-leases as integral trading operations.

holdings.text: The possible reverter of sub-leases does not affect the trading nature of the transactions.

anchor.surface_text: The observations of the Judicial Committee in the case from Rhodesia quoted earlier have our assent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Term 999 years less 2 days; reverter remote, immaterial per British South Africa Co.
